content.description: Start on the underclings at chest level or below. Move straight up through some good horizontal holds to a point where you make a long move into a left gaston crack/pocket. Then smear and high step your way up to the tree.
content.protection: This is a pseudo-high-ball problem. The finishing move getting to the little tree is a little insecure. Watch out! The ground is uneven, and there is a rock sticking out at the top of the mound.
content.location: This is on the furthest left area of the River Wall. There is some green paint on the wall. The problem finishes at a small pine about 25' up. Then walk off left.

content.description:
There are 4 cruxes on this route. Basically, each bulge presents its own challenge.

Heads up: the first bolt is up about 12-15 feet. The rock below the first bolt is not good enough for a bolt, so I didn't put one in. The landing is mulch and flat. Clipping the first bolt and then getting to the 2nd bolt is its own crux. Consider using a stick clip.

Currently, there is a loose block about the size of a 1/2 gallon of ice cream under a small roof just below and left of the 4th bolt. I wailed on it for 30 minutes, and it wouldn't come out. It's a great handhold! So, I think it's usable, but be careful. If you can get it out, great!

Clipping the last bolt is tough. Save some juice for that.

Other than the initial 12' and the loose block, the rock is quite good.
content.location:
This route begins in the same chossy dihedral as

Bare Necessities

. Look up through the overhanging bulges, and you will see a line of bolts.

climbs.name: Toy Story
climbs.fa: Tom Dickey, 1/2004?, 1st bolted lead - Mike Lewis, 5/2/2017

content.description: The crux is at the final bulge. The footholds are small and the wall is overhanging. The bolts on this route are NOT in the ideal placements due to the rock not being ideal for bolt placement - it's good for climbing but not solid enough for a bolt. The bolts are in the closest bomber rock to where you'd ideally want the bolts. The 3rd bolt is most easily clipped from a left-handed layback/sidepull.
content.location: This route ascends dark rock with leaning flakes. It begins 10 feet left of the orange dihedral.

content.description: This is a great little route with delicate moves down low, lots of jugs and sidepulls in the middle, and a stem problem at the top. The crux is moving from the slab through the clean face into the upper groove.
content.location: This route goes up the orange granitic face toward the left side of the River Wall. This is the last "taller" route, as the cliff slabs out just left of this route.

content.description: Leyechen starts with fun, steep crux moves through the first two bolts. From there, continue up the slab through a small overlap toward the orange, well-featured pillar. Climb 3 bolts up the pillar - if you climb to the left of the bolts, the climbing is easier (5.7) and a little dirty. If you climb right of the upper 3 bolts, the climbing is 5.8 on great rock with fun exposed moves. Both variations end up out on the arete to get to the chains.
content.location:
10-15 feet left of "

Mr. Toad's Wild Ride

," look for the vertical, grayish rock that slabs out after 2 bolts and heads into the corner with the orange pillar above.

content.description:
Climb the small, 20-foot right-facing corner, using underclings, sidepulls, and holds out on the face. After the first 25 feet, the route eases to 5.5. The first 2 bolts are placed where the good rock is, though the climbing is to the left. Clipping the 2nd bolt can be tough.

To the right of the 1st 3 bolts is an often wet, mossy streak. To get past the 3rd bolt, the moves can go either way - left into the clean rock or right into the mossy rock. Left is suggested....

Overall, the rock quality is so-so, and it's a bit licheny. It should clean up a bit over time. The opening moves are actually pretty cool.
content.location:
10 feet left of "

Leyechen

," the route climbs a small, overhanging dihedral/corner with a mossy, sometimes, wet streak to the right.

climbs.name: Brother Bear
climbs.fa: Tom Dickey, 1/2004?, 1st bolted lead - Mike Lewis, 5/3/2017?

content.description: The crux of this route is at the very top, pulling through the last bulge. This route will get better and better over time as the lichen and small grains are cleaned off. Unfortunately, the anchors are over the edge at the top, which creates horrible friction for toproping. We considered putting the anchors right at the edge, but then clipping the anchor would have been the crux and it would have ended the flow of the climbing abruptly. So - if you are going to toprope, consider bringing a cordellette up with you and extending the anchor over the edge.
content.location: Start by laybacking a short flake. The first bolt is beside the flake on the right. Continue up small bulges to the final bulge that finishes through a small groove of sorts. This route is left of the orange lichen streak.

content.description: The crux is getting off the ground and up into the crack. Once you are 15 feet off the ground, the climbing gets much easier as the pitch of the wall lessens and slabs out.
content.protection: A singles rack and a 2 anchor bolt with chains.
content.location: Toward the left end of the River Wall, you will see the left-facing crack system that starts with an overhanging bulge to get to the crack. The higher section of the crack is a bit dirty.

content.description:
Just to the right of

Toy Story

is a newly bolted line that climbs on and left of some blank looking rock. The crux is around 3-4 bolts up, getting up to a good ledge on bad feet. Watch out for loose rock as this hasn't seen much traffic yet.

Per

ixf729 Rietz

: climb the corner until you are forced out right to another corner. Changing corners is the crux.

Eds. This is a combination of submission moved to the 1st submission page.
content.location:
Per

ixf729 Rietz

: currently this is the furthest right bolted line on the River Wall starting just left of a large pine with piled up blocks at its base.
